header.title: Intro to International Relations Theories
header.description: A collection of foundational concepts in IR explaining different theoretical perspectives.

title: IR Theories Overview
description: Key schools of thought in international relations, comparing their views on power, institutions, economics, and norms.

concepts.name: Realism
concepts.subtitle: Power politics and state interest
concepts.core_idea: States act primarily to ensure their own survival and power in an anarchic international system.
concepts.short_description: Examines how states pursue power to secure themselves.
concepts.summary_description: Realism posits that the international system is anarchic and states aim to maximize power and security. Conflict is common, and moral considerations are secondary to national interest.

key_assumptions.title: Anarchy
key_assumptions.description: No central authority exists above states in the international system.

key_assumptions.title: Rational actors
key_assumptions.description: States make strategic calculations to protect their survival.

example.title: Cold War Arms Race
example.description: The U.S. and USSR built nuclear arsenals to deter each other and maintain security.

scenario.situation: Two neighboring countries fear each other's military growth.
scenario.what_happens: Each increases defense spending, leading to an arms buildup.

quiz.question: Which action best illustrates Realist thinking?

options.text: Joining a military alliance for security

additional_sections.title: Critiques
additional_sections.content: Realism underplays the role of non-state actors and international norms.

points.title: Static view
points.description: Doesn't easily explain cooperation over time.

concepts.name: Liberalism
concepts.subtitle: Cooperation through institutions and trade
concepts.core_idea: Democratic governance and economic interdependence promote peace and cooperation.
concepts.short_description: Focuses on how institutions and trade reduce conflict.
concepts.summary_description: Liberalism believes that international institutions, democratic governments, and trade ties encourage cooperation and reduce war. Organizations like the UN help mediate disputes.

key_assumptions.title: Institutional power
key_assumptions.description: International organizations help coordinate and enforce agreements.

example.title: European Union
example.description: EU members use shared institutions to resolve conflicts and deepen economic ties.

quiz.question: Which scenario aligns with Liberal theory?

options.text: States forming a trade bloc to boost stability

concepts.name: Institutionalism
concepts.subtitle: Rules shape state behavior
concepts.core_idea: International institutions constrain state behavior and foster cooperation.
concepts.short_description: Highlights the role of formal rules and agreements.
concepts.summary_description: Institutionalism emphasizes how organizations and treaties structure state expectations, reduce uncertainty, and lower costs of cooperation.

key_assumptions.title: Rules matter
key_assumptions.description: Clear frameworks reduce mistrust and cheating.

key_assumptions.title: Repetition builds trust
key_assumptions.description: Ongoing interactions reinforce commitment to cooperation.

example.title: World Trade Organization
example.description: Provides rules and dispute resolution for trade, encouraging compliance.

quiz.question: What role do institutions play according to Institutionalism?

additional_sections.title: Institution vs Theory
additional_sections.content: Institutionalism focuses on actual organizations operating within broader Liberal ideas.

points.title: Enforcement
points.description: Compliance depends on monitoring and sanctions.

concepts.name: Marxist Theory
concepts.subtitle: Economic class and imperialism
concepts.core_idea: International relations are driven by capitalist exploitation and class struggle.
concepts.short_description: Views global politics through economic inequality and class interests.
concepts.summary_description: Marxist theory sees states as instruments of capitalist elites and emphasizes imperialism and exploitation in IR. Economic classes, not states alone, shape world politics.

key_assumptions.title: Capitalism dominates
key_assumptions.description: Economic class relations drive politics more than ideology.

key_assumptions.title: Imperialism persists
key_assumptions.description: Wealthy states exploit poor ones to maximize profits.

example.title: Colonial Extraction
example.description: Colonial powers extracted resources from colonies for profit.

quiz.question: Which is a Marxist critique of IR?

concepts.name: Constructivism
concepts.subtitle: Ideas and identities form reality
concepts.core_idea: State identities and norms shape international relations more than material forces.
concepts.short_description: Explores how ideas influence state interests and actions.
concepts.summary_description: Constructivism argues that international politics are socially constructed‚Äînorms, identities, and discourse shape state interests. Power is not just material, but rooted in ideas.

key_assumptions.title: Identity matters
key_assumptions.description: How states define themselves affects interactions.

example.title: Nuclear Taboo
example.description: A near-universal norm against using nuclear weapons shapes state restraint.

scenario.situation: A rising power refuses to adopt aggressive rhetoric.
scenario.what_happens: Other states treat it as less threatening based on shared norms.

additional_sections.title: Norm Dynamics
additional_sections.content: How norms emerge, spread, and influence behavior over time.
